awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Digital Underwriting Platform for Underserved Borrowers
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will enhance the understanding of predicting default risks for borrowers that lack traditional access to loans and credit. The project will result in a digital platform that efficiently underwrites borrowers for small dollar loans using an innovative technical approach. The project will allow any lender to use the platform to efficiently make small dollar loans, sparing traditionally under-served borrowers from costly alternative financial products. This technology helps financially vulnerable households maintain stability when financial emergencies strike.  

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project develops more effective ways to underwrite small dollar loans for traditionally underserved borrowers. Nearly half of the adults in the U.S. lack a prime credit score that is sufficiently high to allow them access to loans and credit.  Traditional lenders are hesitant to lend to applicants with lower credit scores, due to a perceived higher risk of loss. The systems and information that are used to generate credit scores have limitations that can prohibit credit-worthy borrowers from receiving small dollar loans. The project will investigate alternative methodologies of underwriting small dollar loan applicants. The research will test these alternative methodologies and compare them to traditional credit scoring as a determinant of credit risk, and by extension, loan application approval. Upon completion, the project will demonstrate that an alternative underwriting methodology can generate lower default rates and more equitable lending decisions for small dollar loans when compared to traditional credit scores.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In Salus' Phase I proposal, the company proposed to develop a digital underwriting platform to better serve under-served borrowers. Millions of adults struggle to access credit from traditional lenders due to the prevailing use of credit score in loan underwriting. This lack of access to loans from traditional lenders forces borrowers to use alternative providers, often at significantly higher and punitive costs to the borrower. Salus hypothesized that models utilizing other forms of borrower data could yield better loan performance than methods built around credit scores, and thus expand the ability of traditional lenders to approve loans to borrowers with lower credit scores. The scope of the Phase I proposal focused on developing a platform that would underwrite short-term loans of $50 - $200 more effectively than through the use of credit score.

Our first Phase I objective was to build an API that could ingest raw data and return viable risk scoring in 1-2 seconds. We researched and identified the key lender data that would allow for effective underwriting. However, once we started to receive data, we observed that the variability of data formats created increasing risk of inconsistent outputs. We researched and developed a proprietary model framework that could ingest this data from several sources and formats, yielding clean data and ensuring consistent input and output data from which to gauge model performance.

Our second Phase I objective was to build a structure that would allow the platform to provide regulatory-compliant outputs and performance. We researched and engaged with numerous industry stakeholders, including banks, credit unions, fintech lenders, and regulators. Using the information gleaned from these engagements, we constructed a compliant structure for adverse action notice generation. This allows any borrower to be informed of the reason behind a denial that complies with relevant lending regulations.

Our third Phase I objective was to build a robust and recurring fair lending analysis for the platform. We researched methods and best practices through dialogues with key regulatory agencies. This research allowed us to develop a fully-automated method to test model bias and fairness for applicants, which can be applied to the platform as underwriting models develop.

Our fourth Phase I objective was to develop a model that outperformed credit score risk scoring on loans of $50 to $200. Building on the components of the first three objectives, our goal was to test the model on approximately 700 loans. We achieved our objective, with the modeled approach reducing default rates by 66-74% versus conventional credit score-based underwriting of these small loans.

In addition to the achieved objectives, we were able to expand the scope of Phase I to test the components on larger and longer term loans. Tests on these loans proved as successful, with reduction in default rates similar to the original Phase I sizes and tenors.

We are grateful to the NSF for their SBIR support. This support allowed our company to prove that the use of alternative data can meaningfully improve loan approvals for under-served borrowers without compromising loan performance or regulatory compliance for the lender. Salus plans to continue research on utilizing alternative models to expand access to credit and scaling its initial loan underwriting platform by establishing contractual arrangements with lenders.
